text: Ha I hear you. That’s when you outsource that content to a team member who’s in charge of that list and weekly emails. We send 3 emails a week now and our audience opens and engages with all of them. They are filled with content. And rarely are we asking them to buy anything.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: One last thing. When I rolled out @ReadQuickApp in 2012 I added an email screen. Our list exploded and I decided to email them weekly with speed reading tips and Long Reads that they might’ve missed. The audience loved it. It added tons of additional value for a pricey app.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Just my two marketing cents. I see the email data. Less than once a week and your customers fall off. Ask any company.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: And then when it comes time to roll out Slopes 3.0 they’re engage with you. It’s not a cold email sent 6 months in between the last one. And now you’re asking them to pay for something. For 6 months you could give value in an email that helps them get more out of version 2.0.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: It seems like a lot, but it’s not. Every week I get great content from companies I paid. Less than one email a week is doing them a disservice. You send more than one tweet per day. If Slopes sent me an email once a week with great snow/skiing content I’d read it.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: In all honesty I think that app developers do a disservice to their customers by not engaging them regularly. We think that we’re annoying them. That’s garbage. You built something amazing. They paid you for it. Engage weekly with them.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: No way. Once a week is an absolute minimum.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Can I offer some advice on this? I find it strange but not uncommon that creatives have a hard time with marketing. That list is incredibly important. Why are you not emailing them once or twice a week with tips on how to get more value out of your app?
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Modern cars are essentially computers with wheels. When you turn the wheel you’re not actually turning the tires anymore… a computer is.

text: That’s it. All software. No hardware. That’s a wrap. Now to test it all out! #WWDC14

text: iOS 8 is available today in beta for developers.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Apple announces a new programming language. Goodbye Objective-C. Here’s Swift. Biggest applause of the day.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: So imagine this: say to Siri “time for bed and your HomeKit makes sure your lights are off, garage door is closed, etc.”
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Apple announces HomeKit a unified place for all of your 3rd party home automation apps. Common network protocol. iPhone can open garage door
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Apple is opening up TouchID for 3rd party apps. Bank of America I hope you’re listening. Get on it.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Wow. Apple is letting you download 3rd party keyboards. So Swype? Yep.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Finally Apple is rolling out extensions for iOS. So 3rd party apps can talk to other apps, and be added to notification center.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: @AyseVeli I like it a lot. I own it. But ‘sensation’ implies Beatles like euphoria. I’ve never seen one person holding one.

author: ClaytonMorris

text: Apple announces new pricing for iCloud up to 1 terabytes available.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: Apple announces a new built from the ground up Photos app for the Mac shipping next year. Here’s a preview.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: All of your Photos now available across all of your devices. Stored in iCloud. With a built in search feature.
author: ClaytonMorris

text: New family sharing feature announced. Finally! So when your wife buys a movie you get it too. #WWDC14
author: ClaytonMorris

author: ClaytonMorris

text: Air Drop now works between the Mac and iOS devices. Plus a new added feature called “handoff” which let’s you start something on your Mac..
